projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: CATALOGUE OF BOOKS IN FRIENDS' LIBRARY.

list.head: B.

3. Burroughs Edwards (the Works of a Son of Thunder and Consolation.)
4. Barclay (Truth Triumphant thro' the Spiritual Warfare, by Robert)
5. Bernard (Thesaurus Biblicus, seu promptuarium sacrum, by Richard.)
6. Bishop (a Looking-glass for the Times by) George

list.head: C.

8. The Cambridge Concordance to the Holy Scriptures.

10. Democritus Junior (Anatomy of Melancholy by)

list.head: F.

12. Fox George (Gospel Truth demonstrated in a Collection of doctrinal Books by) containing Principles essential to Christianity and Salvation held among the People called Quakers, 4 Setts.
13. Fox John (Acts and Monuments of the Martyrs by) 3 Vols.

list.head: H.
list.item: 16. Howgil (Dawnings of the Gospel Day by Francis.)
17. Horten Thomas D. D. (forty six Sermons by) on the Epistles of the Apostle Paul.

The Books set down in this Catalogue, and marked with an Asterisk, were the Gift of our much esteemed Friend, Anthony Benezet, late deceased. 18. History of the Rise, Increase and Progress of the People called Quakers, by William Sewell.

list.head: P.

list.head: S.

21. Smith (Balm from Gilead by William.) 3 Setts.
22. Sandy's Travels.

list.head: B.

2. Barclay's Apology.
3. Boroughs Jeremiah (Gospel Conversation.)
4. Bercheniha John (the History of divine Verities by) in three Parts.
5. Baxter Richard (the Saint's everlasting Rest by)
6. Burnyeat John (Truth exalted in the Writings of)
7. Bennet William (a Collection of Epistles and Testimonies of)
8. Buttledore for Teachers and Professors to learn the singular and plural, by George Fox and others.

list.head: C.
list.item: No. 9. Crisp Stephen his Writings.
10. Chalkiey Thomas (a Collection of the Works of) in two Parts.
11. Cloud's Historical Defence of the Reformation.
12. Caryl Joseph (an Exposition upon the Book of Job, by)
13. Collection of remarkable Sermons.
14. Christian Information concerning these last Times, by F.E.

list.head: D.
list.item: 15. Dewsberry William (The Faithful Testimony of)

list.head: E.
list.item: 16. Ellwood Thomas (an Antidote against the Infection of William Rogers's Book, miscalled the Quaker distinguished from the Apostate and Innovator by) 2 Setts.
17. Erbury William (Testimony of) being a Collection of his Writings, whereunto is added the honest Heretic, being his Trial at Westminster.
18. AEneidos (the thirteen Books of) in English Verse.—
19. Edmundson William (Journal of the Life, Travels &c. of) 2 Setts.
* 20. Epistles from the Meeting for Sufferings and other Meetings, (Collection of)

list.head: F.
list.item: 21 Foster Mary on Various Subjects.

list.head: G.

23. Glanville Joseph (Scepsis scientifica, or confessed Ignorance the Way to Science by)

list.head: H.

25. Holy Bible—2—* 1 Copy.

list.head: I.

27. Independent Whig.

list.head: M.

list.head: N.
list.item: No. 29. Naylor James, (the Works of)

32. P. W. (the Guide mistaken, and temporising rebuked, by)
33. Paul's Epistles in Manuscript.
34. Pennington Isaac (the Works of)
35. Pennington Isaac the Younger, (the Jew outward, being a Glass for the Professors of this Age. by)
36. Prynne William (Histriomastix, or the Player's Scourge and Actor's Tragedy, in 2 Parts by—)
37. Pennington Isaac (the Works of) in 2 Vols.

list.head: R.
list.item: 38. Rutty John (History of the Rise and Progress of the People called Quakers, in Ireland) by
* 39. Rise and Progress of the People called Quakers, in Ireland by Thomas Wight, of Cork.

list.head: S.
list.item: 43. The Soul's Humiliation.
41. Sufferings of Friends in New-England.
42. A Spirit of the Martyrs revived.

list.head: T.
list.item:
43. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Arrows against Babylon, by John Pandarves, and Endeavours for Reformation in Saints Apparel.
2. A Discourse touching the Peace and Concord of the Church.
3. A Collection of Writings on the Trinity.
4. Jura Populi Anglicana, or the Subject's Right of petitioning set forth.
5. A Sermon before the Queen and Parliament, by the Bishop of Exeter.
6. A Le •• er on two Sermons.
7. Lord Haversham's Speech, in the House of Peers.

44. II. A Collection of Tracts, Tiz.
1. Christian Information, concerning these last Times.
2. What the Possession of the living Faith is, and its Fruits.
3. A General Epistle to all Friends in Verse, by William Bailey.
4. An Alarm from the holy Mountain of the Lord, to the Inhabitants of the Earth.
No. 5. Quakers Plea with the Bishops at their Ecclesiastical Courts, by Richard Farnsworth.
6. A Controversy between the Quakers and Bishops.
7. Trial and Examination of Margaret Fell, and George Fox.
8. A true and impartial Narration of remarkable Providences of the Living God, appearing for Nicholas Lucas, Henry Marshall, and others, who were sentenced to be transported beyond the Seas, for meeting to wait upon the Lord their Maker.
9. A second Relation of unjust Proceedings, of some called Justices, upon the Trial of twenty one Persons, called Quakers.
10. A Remonstrance against the Act, to prevent and suppress seditious Conventicles, by Albertus Otto Faber.
11. A retrospective Glass for Legislators, by E. B.
12. Christian religious Meetings, allowed by the Liturgy.
13. A brief Relation of the Proceedings against the Prisoners called Quakers, in London, at Hicks Hall, and Old Bailey, on the 14th, 15th, and 17th, October, 1664.
14. A Tender Visitation of Heavenly Love, by Richard Farnsworth, I. Whitehead, and Thomas Green.
15. A second Relation of the unjust Proceedings at Hicks Hall, and the Old Bailey.
16. A friendly Exhortation to the Children of Truth, to be valiant in this Day of Trial, by William Brend.
17. A third Relation of Proceedings at Hicks Hall, and Old Bailey.
18. The wounded Heart, or the Juryman's Offences declared, and ingeniously acknowledged, by Thomas Leader, for the Satisfaction of those who were thereby troubled.
19. The Voice of the Innocent, being a brief Relation of some remarkable Passages, in the Trials of five of the People of God called Quakers, at the Castle of Northampton.
20. The Word of the Lord to all Children born again of the immortal Seed, by William Dewsbury.
21. Vindication of the Principles and Practices of the People called Quakers, by George Bishop.
22. The great Case of Tythes, and forced Maintenance, revived.
23. A few Words to the Professors of the Protestant Religion, by F. E.
24. The Cause of the Widows and Fatherless, pleaded with the Judges and Magistrates of England, by T. R.

No. 45. III. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. A Testimony of the true Light of the World, by G. Fox.
2. An Address to the Parliament of England, by Ditto.
3. The Priests and Professors Catechism, by Ditto.
4. A Declaration of the Ground of Errors, &c. by Ditto.
5. A Visitation to the Jews. by Ditto.
6. A Love to the Lost, and a Hand to lead the Helpless out of the Dark, by J. Naylor.
7. A Standard lifted up, and an Ensign held forth, to all Nations by Edward Burroughs.
8. Truth witnessed forth in the Spirit of Truth, against all Deceit, being a Reply to John Bunyan's Vindication, &c. by Ditto.
9. Plain Dealing, with the Army of the Commonwealth of England, by George Fox the younger.
10. The great Trumpet of the Lord founded out unto those that are ready to perish, by John Moon.
11. Man driven out of the Earth and Darkness, by Humphrey Smith.
12. Relation of the Commitment and unjust Imprisonment of James Potter, Ann Potter, &c.
13. The Blood of righteous Abel, by Wm. Bailey.
14. A Letter to the Musicians, Singers, &c. by H. S.
15. The Sins of a rebellious People, laid before them, by John Rouse.
16. Letter to the Parliament at Westminster, by H. Bache.
17. An Eastern Reckoning, or Free-Will Offering.
18. The Banner of Gods Love, and Ensign of Righteousness, written by Ambrose Rigg.
19. The proud Pharisee reproved, or the lying Orator laid open, by Martin Mason.
20. The Path of the Just cleared, or Cruelty laid open.
21. The West answering to the North, in the Relation of the Sufferings of George Fox, and others.
22. The Declaration of the Sufferings and Persecutions sustained by the People called Quakers, of the City of Bristol.
23. The Lamb's Defence against Lies.

46. IV. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Cry of the Innocent for Justice, being the Trial of John Crook, and others, in three Parts.
2. A Monthly Intelligencer, relating the Affairs of the People called Quakers, in and near the City of London; concerning the Violence and Persecution brought forth against them, from 1st 6th Mo. to 1st 7th Mo.
3. A short Relation of some cruel Sufferings of Catharine Evans and Sarah Chivers, in the Inquisition of the Isle of Malta.
No. 4. A clear Voice of Truth founded forth, by Daniel Baker.
5. A General Epistle to all Friends, by G. F.
6. An Answer to the Arguments of the Jews, in which they go about to prove the Messiah is not come, by G. Fox.
7. A Measuring Rule, concerning Liberty and Persecution, by George Fox.
8. Blow at Babel, in those of the People called Behmenites, by John Anderson.
9. Christ's Light brought to Light, in Latin and English.
10. The Bishop busied beside the Business, by Samuel Fisher, in two Parts.

47. V. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. The People's ancient and just Liberties, asserted at the Trial of William Penn and William Meade.
2. An Answer to John Wiggin's Book, by Thomas Curwen and others.
3. The second Part of the People's ancient and just Liberties asserted in the trials of Thomas Rudyard, Francis Moore, Richard Mew and others.
4. The due Order of Law and Justice pleaded against irregular and arbitrary Proceeding in the Case of George Whitehead and Thomas Burr.
5. The continued Cry of the Oppressed for Justice, by the Author of England's present Interest.
6. A particular Account of the Sufferings of the People called Quakers, upon Prosecutions against them in Bishops Courts.
7. The Liberty of the Subject, by Magna Charta.
8. A brief Account of the Sufferings of the People called Quakers, by Ellis Hooks.
9. The Christian Principles of the People called Quakers, with respect to the King and Government, asserted.
10. Forced Uniformity, neither Christian nor prudent.
11. A faithful Warning to the Rulers and Magistrates in England, by Alexander Lawrence.
12. The Plea of the harmless oppressed, against the cruel Oppressor, by Thomas Exon.
13. A just Complaint of the oppressed, examined by the Law of God and Nations, in pregnant Instances.
14. A true and impartial Narrative, of some illegal and arbitrary Proceedings of certain Justices, against several Non-Conformists in or near the Town of Bedford, with a brief Account of the late sudden and strange Death of the grand Informer.
15. A Declaration against all Sedition, Plotters, and Fighters in the World. (Inserted twice.)
No. 16. Several Reasons why no outward Force, on Conscience, ought to be used in Matters of Faith and Religion.
17. An Address to Magistrates, Governors and Rulers, in England.
18. A Declaration to the King and both Houses of Parliament.
19. Case of the People called Quakers, stated to the King, Lords, and Commons.
20. An Account of Seizures and Sequestrations.
21. Sufferings and Passages of Miles Halhead.

48. VI. A Collection of Tracts, viz.
1. Truth cleared of Calumnies, by Robert Barclay.
2, The Libeller characterised (by his own Hand.)
3. A brief Answer to three Books, put forth against the People called Quakers.
4. The Babylonish Baptist.
5. The Anabaptist's lying Wonder, attested by his Brother Independent.
6. The new Witnesses proved old Heretics.
7. The lying Spirits turned Home again, by J. W.
8. The Way of God vindicated against Deceit and Lies, by James Parke.
9. The apostate Incendiary rebuked, by George Whitehead.
10. The Seat of the Scorner thrown down, by Luke Howard.
11. The Water Baptist's Reproach, repelled by T. R.
12. The Quaker's Refuge fixed upon the Rock of Ages.
13. Daniel Smith's Sign.
14. The Spirit of Alexander the Coppersmith, justly rebuked, by W. P.
15. Urim and Thummim, or the apostolical Doctrine of Light and Perfection maintained.
16. A just Rebuke to twenty-one Divines, by William Penn.
17. The timorous Revilers slighted, by G. W.
18. William Penn and the Quaker in Unity, by William Shewen,
19. The ungrateful Almsman rebuked.
20. The false Witness examined and rebuked.
21. The Universality of the Light, which shines in Darkness, Asserted by W. Shewen.
22. A Second Testimony concerning Swearing, by Jervase Benson.
23. An Answer to Doctor Good's Dialogue, against those called Quakers.
24. A Testimony against Jeffery Bullock's Antichristian, and Foolish Pamphlet.
25. The Innocent cleared, and the Guilty made manifest, by Samuel Cater.
26. A Testimony for Christ Jesus, against W. Haworth's pretended Antidote, against the Quakers.
27. Ditto. of the Harford Quakers.
28. The Devil the greatest Sinner in the World, by John Haughtor.
29. A Vindication of Jesus Christ, by J. Vaoghton.
30. The Skirmisher Consounder, by Roger Haydock.
31. A Relation of a public Dispute at Triploe.
32. The Malice of the Rebellious Husbandman, against the true Heir.
33. The Skirmisher defeated, and Truth defended.
34. Quakerism confirm'd, by R. Barclay, and G. Keith.
35. A Faithful Warning to outside Professors.
36. The Life of God exalted.

No. 50. VII. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Life of Enoch, again revived.
2. A Clear Voice of Truth sounded forth, by Daniel Baker.
3. The Sufferings of Catherine Evans, and Sarah Chevers, in the Isle of Malta.
4. An Epistle to all sincere hearted Souls, by John Perrot.
5. The Mystery of Baptism, and the Lords Supper, by Ditto.
6. An Epistle for Unity, to prevent the Wiles of the Enemy, by John Crooke.
7. The Cry of the Innocent for Justice, being a Relation of the Trial of John Crooke and others.
8. An Invitation of Love to the seed of God throughout the World, by John Brooksop,
9. An Epistle to the Clergy of the Liturgy.
10. An Epistle of Love and Consolation to Israel, by D. W.
11. An Epistle from Newgate Prison.
12. Case of the Quakers published to the World.
13. A Warning from the Lord to the Rulers of Dover, by Luke Howard.
14. The pernicious Way of the rigid Presbyter detected, by George Whitehead.
15. The Reason why the People called Quakers cannot go to Worship at Churches and Chapels, by Ditto.
16. A Book of Warnings; the Visitation of the Lord's Love, by George Bishop.
17. A Salutation of Love to the Seed of God, by Ditto.
18. The last Trump, or one Warning more yet, by Ditto.
19. An Epistle of Love, by Ditto.
20. A Call from God out of Egypt, by D. W.
21. A Treatise concerning the Resurrection, by George Bishop.
22. An Apology for the Quakers, by G. Crook.
23. Truth's Principles, &c. by G. Crook.

No. 51. VIII. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Spirit of Truth vindicated, by W. P.
2. Truth rescued from Imposture, by Ditto.
3. The Skirmisher defeated, by Ditto.
4. Spirit of Alexander the Coppersmith rebuked.
5. Urim and Thummim, by W. P.
6. Truth cleared of Calumny, by R. Barclay.
7. Counterfeit Convert discovered, by John Cook and William Bailey.
8. The Glory of Christs Light within expelling Darkness, by George Whitehead.
9. A Demonstration of a Dialogue between a Christian and a Quaker, by Robert West.
10. The Universality of the Light which shines in Darkness asserted, by William Shewen.
11. Case of the Quakers concerning Oaths defended, as evangelical, by—
12. A general Epistle, by James Parke.

52. IX. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Truth and innocency vindicated, by George Whitehead.
2. A new way of reading the Bible, according to the three Norfolk Clergymen.
3. An Apology for the people called Quakers, and appeal to the Inhabitants of Norfolk and Suffolk, by J.P.
4. Some Account from Colchester of the unfairness and disingenuity of two Rectors, in their account against the Quaker.
5. A Just and Righteous Plea, presented to the King of England and Council, by Edward Burroughs.
6. The Light of Truth triumphing over Darkness and Ignorance, Error and Envy, by G. Keith and G. Whitehead.
7. A Treatise of Election and Reprobation, by B. L.
8. An address to the Protestants, upon the present Conjuncture, by William Penn.

53. X. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. Some Principles of the People of God called Quakers, by I. Pennington.
2. A Testimony of what we believe of Christ &c, by George Fox.
3. A Hypocrite unveiled, by Roger Haydock.
4. The independent Agent, an expostulatory Appeal to the professors of Christianity, by Richard Thomas and others.
5. An Answer to a Book published by Alexander Lawrence.
6. The Spirit of Man the Candle of the Lord, by George Fox.
7. An Epistle to the Churches of Christ throughout the World, by William Penn.
8. A Testimony against Perry-Wigs and Perry-Wig making, by John Mulliner.
9. Tender Salutation to the Flock in Ireland, by Samuel Wallingfield and John Ralett.
10. A Testimony for all the Masters and Seamen of Ships to read over, by George Fox.
11. A Warning to the People in Barbadoes, by Lydia Fell.
12. The Daughter of Sion awakened, by M. F.
13. Hat Honour to Men, Mans Institution, not Gods, by George Fox.
14. A Testimony concerning Justification, by Ditto.
15. Christ's Parable of Dives and Lazarus, by Ditto.
16. An Epistle to all who profess the Light of Jesus Christ within to be their Guide.
17. A Christian Testimony against Tythes, by Thomas Atkinson.
18. The Shibboleth of Priesthood, by B. Lindley.
19. Christian Unity exhorted to.
20. The Everlasting Gospel of our Lord, by Isaac Penington.
21. An Epistle to the Children of Light, by William Penn.
22. Brief answer to a Libel, called the Quaker's Principles, by William Penn.
23. The Pamphlet of the Lyar discovered, by James Peterson.
24. An Answer to several new Laws and Orders made by the Rulers of Boston.
25. Gibson William, Election and Reprobation scripturally witnessed unto.
26. Answer to a Book called the hidden Things brought to Light by Robert Rich.
27. The Man Christ Jesus the Head of the Church, by George Fox.
28. A warning to London in particular, by James Parke.
29. A warning to all Friends, by Mary Waite.
30. A warning to England, by James Parke.
31. Reason why the Oath should not be made a part of the Test to Protestant Dissenters.
32. An Adress to Protestants upon the present Conjuncture, by William Penn.

54. XI. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. The People's ancient and just Liberties asserted, in the Trial of William Penn and William Meade.
2. An Humble Application to the Queen and Parliament, to suppress Play Houses, by John Field.
3. An Epistle of Love and Advice to the Churches throughout the World by William Crisp.
4. An Epistle of Farewell to the People called Quakers in Europe, by William Penn.
5. An Epistle to the Children of Light, in this Generation by Ditto.
6. The Christian Principle and Conversation of the People called Quakers to the King and Government, asserted.
7. An Epistle of tender Love to all the Flock of God, by William Bingley.
8. The Christian Principle &c. again as above.
9. A sober Vindication of the Religious Assemblies of the People called Quakers.
10. A seasonable Dissuasive from Persecution, by T. Ellwood.
11. A Lamentation over England, by William Bingley.
12. Concerning Persecution in all Ages to this day, by G. Fox.
13. An Encouragement for all to trust in the Lord, by Ditto.
14. An Exhortation to them that profess themselves Christians, by Ditto.
15. A Test and protest against popery.
16. Jacob the plain prevailing against Esau the rough and cunning Man.
17. The Trumpet of the Lord founded, by Charles Marshall.
18. The Upright Lives of the Heathen briefly noted.
19. An Epistle of tender Love, by William Bingley.
20. A Relation of the Life and Death of William Simpson in Barbadoes.
21. The Devil the old Informer against the Righteous, by George Fox.
22. A word of Admonition to Wanderers, by Ditto.
23. A second Epistle being a tender salutation to the seed of Jacob, by Charles Marshall.
24, An address to the King and Parliament, by John Stubbs.
25. An Epistle of Love to all that are in present Suffering, by John Crooke.
26. A call and Visitation to Christendom, by William Bailey.
27. An Epistle general, by George Fox.
28. The Anarchy of the Ranters, by Robert Barclay.
29. A short Relation of some part of the sufferings of the People called Quakers.
30. The Everlasting Gospel of Repentance, by E. Burrough.
31. Innocence against Envy, by G. W. and S. C.
32. The Popish Informer reprehended.
33. A short Testimony, by Thomas Aldam.
34. The Skirmisher defeated, by William Penn.
35. Christ's Lambs defended from Satans Rage, by George Whitehead.

55. XII. A Collection of Tracts, Viz.
1. The true Ministers of the Gospel distinguished from the false, by G. W. and I. N.
2. A Word of Reproof to the Teachers of the World, by Stephen Crisp.
3. A Dispute between James Naylor and the Parish Teachers of Chesterfield.
4. A just Plea against swearing, by James Picton.
5. The Public Worship, or the Worship of God, by R. F.
6. Some Queries of the Order and Government of the Church of Christ.
7. The deceitful Spirit discovered, &c.
8. Queries given forth, for any to answer if they can.
9. Plain words concerning conformity in matter of Religion and Worship.
10. Truth owned and Deceit denied, by Patrick Livingston.
11. The art of Music discoursed on, by a Musician, a Baptist and a Quaker, by Solomon Eccles.
12. The Quakers Challenge at two several Weapons, by Ditto.
13. Christ ascended above the Clouds, by George Whitehead.
14. Some Considerations proposed to Psalm-Singers, by Edward Cooke.
15. Testimony for Truth against Hirelings, by Judith Boulbie.
16. The Light of Truth Triumphing over Darkness, and Ignorance, Error and Envy, by G. W.
17. The Popish Informer reprehended, for false Information against the Quakers Meetings, by G. W. and W. S.
18. A General Summons from the Authority of Truth, by William Smith.
19. Queries to the Bishops, and Ministers.
20. The Heathen's Divinity, set upon the Heads of those called Christians.
